text:
My cold call is, is he a
transformational leader?

This is a person who is
not only himself a winner,
but is able to influence others.

What's interesting is that when
you actually are around him ----

regular guy, engaged,
deeply thoughtful, really
understands people, and listens.

He learned sports by playing
football and baseball
at the same time.

The way football players
operate and baseball players

operate are
drastically different,

but he got to know the
owners and the GMs,

and start to understand
how organizations run.

He has what I would call an
old-school coaching style.

He holds kids
accountable, and he

expects them to
follow his core values

of being smart,
tough, disciplined
and having some character.

He deeply knows his people
and pulls people around him.

He trusts his people
and doesn't micromanage.

That's a heck of an impact
for one person who came

into a 1-and-11 team and
now is turning it around.

And because he's able
to create a vision

and be present for the duration,
operationalize for others,

empower others, that's
the basic definition
of a transformational leader.

And he hits all of
those outside the mark.

Leadership is a
contact sport, and I

think no one does it
better than Deion Sanders.
